comments:
Repro steps:

1. Make a program that includes this:

        boolean b = true;
        System.out.println("break here");

2. Set a breakpoint on the println line, and debug.
3. When you hit the breakpoint, notice variable 'b', value 'true' in the Variables view.
4. Click where it says 'true'.  You get a dropdown box with "true" and "false" in it.  Try clicking "false" in the list; works fine, changes the value to false.
5. Now click on the value again, and just type "true" (without quotes).

Actual result: Error message: "An error has occurred. See error log for more details."  In the error log is this:

Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in: "org.eclipse.jface".

Expected result:
Either you should be able to type "true" and "false", or (perhaps easier) there is no need to have the dropdown be editable -- just require that the user click on "true" or "false", without allowing him to type a value.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 140370 ***
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991
